photo.description: Castello Sforzesco (English: Sforza Castle) is a castle in Milan, Italy, that used to be the seat and residence of the ruling family of Milan and now houses several of the city's museums and art collections. The original construction on the site began in the 14th century. In 1450, Francesco Sforza began reconstruction of the castle, and it was further modified by later generations. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Castello_Sforzesco
photo.tags: milano italy europe 2010 travel
photo.title: Milano Castello Sforzesco

photo.tags: milano italy europe 2010 travel
photo.title: Milano Castello Sforzesco

photo.description: Castello Sforzesco (English: Sforza Castle) is a castle in Milan, Italy, that used to be the seat and residence of the ruling family of Milan and now houses several of the city's museums and art collections. The original construction on the site began in the 14th century. In 1450, Francesco Sforza began reconstruction of the castle, and it was further modified by later generations. A number of these rooms originally had elaborate internal decoration - the best known of these being the Sala Delle Asse with surviving ceiling paintings by Leonardo da Vinci After the French victory in the 1515 Battle of Marignano, the defeated Massimiliano Sforza, his Swiss mercenaries and the cardinal-bishop of Sion retreated into the Castello Sforzesco. However, King Francis I of France followed them into Milan, and his sappers placed mines under the castle's foundations, whereupon the defenders submited. After the unification of Italy in the 19th century, the restoration of the castle was started following its transfer from military use to the city of Milan. The restoration work was directed by Luca Beltrami. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Castello_Sforzesco
photo.tags: milano italy europe 2010 travel panorama
photo.title: Castello Sforzesco panorama

photo.description: The Sforza castle gate through the wall beneath the Torre del Filarete tower.
photo.tags: italia italy milano milan castellosforzesco sforzacastle torredelfilarete
photo.title: Sforza castle gate

photo.description: Looking up on the impressibe Torre del Filarete from just outside the main gate to the Sforza castle. I'm not sure which person, if any, is on the monument - but the coat of arms on either side of it is that of the House of Sforza - with the blue serpent of the Visconti combined with the black eagle with a crown and outstretched wings.
photo.tags: italia italy milano milan castellosforzesco sforzacastle torredelfilarete houseofsforza houseofvisconti
photo.title: Torre del Filarete

photo.description: The north eastern gate to the Sforza castle in Milan with the House of Sforza coat of arms above the entrance. The blue serpent, who appears to be swallowing a human, was also used on the earlier House of Visconti coat of arms - the Sforza family took it over and just added the black eagle to make it their own coat of arms.

photo.description: Castello Sforzesco (English: Sforza Castle) is a castle in Milan, Italy, that used to be the seat and residence of the ruling family of Milan and now houses several of the city's museums and art collections. The original construction on the site began in the 14th century. In 1450, Francesco Sforza began reconstruction of the castle, and it was further modified by later generations. A number of these rooms originally had elaborate internal decoration - the best known of these being the Sala Delle Asse with surviving ceiling paintings by Leonardo da Vinci After the French victory in the 1515 Battle of Marignano, the defeated Massimiliano Sforza, his Swiss mercenaries and the cardinal-bishop of Sion retreated into the Castello Sforzesco. However, King Francis I of France followed them into Milan, and his sappers placed mines under the castle's foundations, whereupon the defenders submited. After the unification of Italy in the 19th century, the restoration of the castle was started following its transfer from military use to the city of Milan. photo.title: Castello Sforzesco

photo.description: An old and worn sign above the gate, which hasn't been used in centuries, informs modern tourists that this was once the gate of the Visconti castle. Before the Sforza family moved in, the castle was the property of the ruling Visconti family who had constructed the original castle around 1360. The Sforza family came to power in 1447, when Francesco I Sforza - the son-in-law of the last Visconti duke - established the reign of the House of Sforza. So this gate must be older than 1447.
photo.tags: italia italy milano milan castellosforzesco portadelcastellovisconteo
photo.title: Porta del Castello Visconteo

photo.description: Information board in the courtyard of the Sforza castle, with a drawing of the castle as it was in the 18th century. The castle had lost its role as ducal residence during the Spanish occupation (1535-1706), so during the Austrian occupation (1706-96) it was used for shelter and stalls by Austrian troops.
photo.tags: italia italy milano milan castellosforzesco sforzacastle
photo.title: Castello Sforzesco

photo.description: Torre del Filarete, over the main entrance to the Sforza castle, is named after Antonio de Pietro Averulino (1400 - 1469) also known as "il Filarete", the Renaissance artist who helped design the castle.
photo.tags: italia italy milano milan castellosforzesco sforzacastle torredelfilarete
photo.title: Torre del Filarete

photo.description: The Filarete tower, above the main city entrance, was rebuilt between 1900 and 1905 as a monument to the then recently dead Italian monarch Humberto Primo (Umberto I) who had ruled Italy from 1878 to 1900. The king is seen in this stone monument, built into the tower wall.
photo.tags: italia italy milano milan castellosforzesco sforzacastle torredelfilarete humbertoprimo umbertoi
photo.title: Humberto Primo

photo.title: Castello Sforzesco

photo.description: The statue of San Giovanni Nepomuceno in front of Bona di Savoia tower inside the Sforza castle in Milan. The tower was built by Bona di Savoia or Bona of Savoy (1449-1503), the wife of Galeazzo Maria Sforza and one of the most powerful women of the period in Europe. When her husband was assassinated, in the church of Santo Stefano in 1476, she took charge to help her 10 year old son rule the city of Milan. She built her tower not as a form of defence against potential invaders, but in order to keep a watchful eye on her brother-in-law, Ludovico Maria Sforza. But to no avail: in 1480, Ludovico kidnapped her son, exiled Bona, and had her advisor Cicco Simonetta decapitated. Ludovico Maria Sforza, nicknamed "Il Moro" (the Moor), would go on to become one of the most influential Renaissance patrons - inviting among others Leonardo da Vinci to stay and work in Milan. Until Il Moro himself was taken prisoner by French troops in the spring 1500, Milan experienced an artistic renaissance like never before or after.
photo.tags: italia italy milano milan castellosforzesco sforzacastle johnofnepomuk sangiovanninepomuceno bonadisavioa bonaofsavoy
photo.title: Bona di Savoia

photo.description: This statue represents a saint named San Giovanni Nepomuceno (John of Nepomuk), the patron saint and protector of the Austrian troops. John of Nepomuk was a Christian martyr who lived from 1345-93 in what is now the Czech republic. The statue was installed in 1752, about two decades after he was canonized under Pope Benedict XIII.
photo.tags: italia italy milano milan castellosforzesco johnofnepomuk sangiovanninepomuceno sforzacastle
photo.title: San Giovanni Nepomuceno

photo.title: milano_11.11.2010_5333

photo.description: The awe-inspiring size of Sforza's Castle is reason enough to take a tour of its secret passages. Built by the ruling Visconti-Sforza family in the early 15th century, the castle served as both a sumptuous ducal residence and as a virtually impregnable fortress protecting the city.
photo.tags: italia italy milano milan castellosforzesco sforzacastle
photo.title: Castello Sforzesco

photo.description: The north eastern gate to the Sforza castle in Milan looks just as imposing as it did back in the 15th century, with a drawbridge that could be raised and lowered and the Sforza family coat of arms above the gate. This drawbridge is a reconstruction, like much of the wall and towers. Originally there were 62 drawbridges leading into the castle.
photo.tags: italia italy milano milan castellosforzesco sforzacastle
photo.title: Castle gate

photo.description: Founded by the Visconti family at the end of the 14th C., this immense square building has been greatly renovated in the Renaissance style by the Sforza family. Here we find the two families that held power over Milan.
photo.tags: italia italy milano milan castellosforzesco sforzacastle
photo.title: Castello Sforzesco

photo.description: Information board by the north eastern gate of the Sforza castle in Milan. It states that the origins of the castle date to 1368 when Galeazzo II Visconti, lord of Milan, commissioned a fortified structure to be built on the walls of the city to defend the medieval gate. Reinforced by Visconti successors the castle was a strong defense against enemies, both outside and inside the city. During the Golden Ambrosian Republic in 1447 the castle, a symbol of past tyranny, was systematically destroyed by the furor of the populace. Francesco Sforza, the Duke of Milan from 1450-66, wanted to rebuild the castle in a more majestic fashion than the previous. For this he called on the leading architects of his time. His successor would continue to enlarge and enrich the castle, making it into a popular Rennaissane court in Milan hosting such historic figures as Donato Bramante and Leonardo da Vinci.
photo.tags: italia italy milano milan castellosforzesco sforzacastle
photo.title: Castello Sforzesco

photo.description: The park also sits next to the Sforza Castle. The very design of the park, due to architect Emilio Alemagna, was conceived with the intent of creating panoramic views encompassing both monuments - the castle and the arch.
photo.tags: castellosforzesco castle duchyofmilan historic italia italy lombardia lombardy medieval milan milano parcosempione park sforza sforzacastle
photo.title: Castello Sforzesco

photo.description: This information board at the Archaeological Museum in Milan shows the expansion of the city from Antiquity to modern times. The red area represents 1st century Mediolanum, when it was 0,8 square km large and had some 20 thousand citizens. This was about the time it was given full Roman citizenship. The pink and red areas shows the size of 12th century Milan, when the Sforza castle (the black box) was built. The size is about 2,4 square km but the population is not known. The orange, pink and red areas shows the size of 16th century Milan, when it was 8 square km large and had a population of 50-60 thousand. The yellow and green areas show the city limits in 1873 and 1923. The city borders has not changed since then. Today the city has an area of 183 square km and is home to 1,3 million (down from a peak population of 1,7 mill in 1974).
photo.tags: italia italy milano milan archaeologicalmuseum mediolanum
photo.title: From Mediolanum to Milan
